questions.text: A 45-year-old male presents with cough, nasal discomfort and weight loss. He has a travel history to South America in the past. On examination, he is found to have ulcerative granulomas on his nasal and buccal mucosa. A microscopic examination of the lesion is shown below. Which is the most likely causative organism?
questions.solution:
Answer: C) Paracoccidioides

 

Explanation:

Based on the travel history, clinical manifestation and characteristic mariner’s or pilot’s wheel appearance on microscopy, the most probable diagnosis is Paracoccidioidomycosis. It is caused by Paracoccidioides brasiliensis.

 

Paracoccidioidomycosis

Causative agent

Thermally dimorphic fungus Paracoccidioides brasiliensis. (Option C)

Epidemiology

Confined to South America, it is called South American blastomycosis.

Route of transmission

Inhalation of spores

Clinical features

Chronic granulomatous disease of the skin, mucosa, lymph nodes and internal organs.

Primary pulmonary infection spreads by the hematogenous route to the mucosa of the nose, mouth, gastrointestinal tract, skin and lymphatics.

Ulcerative granulomas of the buccal, and nasal mucosa.

Diagnosis

 

In tissue: Yeast phase - large, globose or oval cells with multiple buds encircling the mother cell giving a mariner's wheel or pilot's wheel or Mickey Mouse appearance.


 

Culture: Mycelial phase

Treatment

 

Itraconazole is the drug of choice

 

Histoplasma (Option A): It causes histoplasmosis, especially in immunocompromised patients. It can cause pulmonary and systemic infections. Microscopy shows small intra- and extracellular yeast cells. This option is incorrect.

Blastomyces (Option B): It causes blastomycosis. It primarily causes pulmonary symptoms and may disseminate to the skin, bones, and other organs. The yeast form of Blastomyces is typically large, thick-walled, and appears as single broad-based buds. This option is incorrect.

 

Cryptococcus (Option D): It causes cryptococcosis, primarily in immunocompromised individuals. It commonly presents as a pulmonary or central nervous system infection, but mucosal involvement is rare. The yeast cells of Cryptococcus are typically round or oval, single-celled, and surrounded by a thick capsule, with no multiple budding patterns. This option is incorrect.

questions.text:
A 45-year-old male with a history of AIDS presents to the clinic with persistent fever, significant weight loss over the past month, and cough that has worsened over the last two weeks. He resides in a rural area of Southeast Asia, where he frequently encounters bamboo rats. On physical examination, he has cervical lymphadenopathy and hepatomegaly. A sputum sample is collected for microbiological examination. An image is shown below. Which of the following is characteristic of the colony that is likely to grow in culture from this patient’s sputum sample?


{{caption_text}}

choices.text: Green, granular colonies with a distinctive red pigment
Creamy white, smooth colonies and with a yeasty odour

questions.solution:
Answer: B) Green, granular colonies with a distinctive red pigment

 

Explanation:

Given the patient's symptoms, history of exposure to bamboo rats, and immunocompromised status due to AIDS, microscopy showing septate hyphae with branched conidiophores, the likely pathogen is Talaromyces marneffei. This fungus produces green, granular colonies with a distinctive red pigment that diffuses into the agar when cultured on Sabouraud agar, which is a characteristic feature of this organism.

Penicillium marneffei

Characteristics

Currently, the name is changed to Talaromyces marneffei.

Thermally dimorphic fungus

Causes

Talaromycosis (Penicilliosis)

Epidemiology

Common in Southeast Asia, southern China, and northeastern India.

High incidence in AIDS and immunocompromised patients.

Reservoir

Bamboo rat

Route of transmission

Inhalation of fungal spores

No person-to-person transmission

Clinical manifestations

It affects the reticuloendothelial system, causing lymphadenopathy, hepatomegaly, and splenomegaly.

Lung involvement is common.

Increased risk of dissemination in AIDS and immunocompromised individuals.

Specimens for Diagnosis

Bone marrow, blood, sputum, lymph nodes, skin lesions

Diagnosis

Culture on Sabouraud Agar:

  • Green, granular colonies with a distinctive red pigment that diffuses into the agar.

Microscopy:

  • Septate hyphae with branched conidiophores

showing a brush-like arrangement of spores

 

Additional Tests:

  • Antigen testing (urine/serum) and PCR

Treatment

Amphotericin B (IV for two weeks), followed by Itraconazole.

Others: Voriconazole, Posaconazole.

 

White, cottony, mycelial growth (Option A): It is typically associated with Histoplasma capsulatum. This option is incorrect.

 

Smooth, mucoid, cream-coloured colonies (Option C): It is typically associated with Cryptococcus neoformans. This option is incorrect.

 

Creamy white, smooth colonies and with a yeasty odour (Option D): It is typically associated with Candida albicans. This option is incorrect.

questions.text: What microscopic features are not observed when examining cultures of Histoplasma capsulatum?
questions.solution:
Answer: D) Intracellular yeast cells

 

Explanation:

Intracellular yeast cells are seen in stained tissue samples or body fluids during microscopic examination and not in cultures.

Microscopic examination of Yeast in histoplasmosis:

  • Culture:
    • Blood agar and Sabouraud agar show White, cottony growth
  • Microscopy:
    • From culture colonies: Mycelial growth with large thick-walled spherical spores with tuberculate (Tuberculate macroconidia) and smooth-walled oval microconidia (Options A, B & C ruled out)
  • Stained smears of the specimens: Show small intra- and extracellular yeast cells (Option D)

questions.text: A 35-year-old male from a tropical region presents with nasal obstruction, epistaxis, and a soft, fleshy nasal mass. Histopathological examination reveals thick-walled sporangia filled with endospores and hyperplastic tissue without eosinophilic infiltration. Which of the following statements regarding this condition is correct?

choices.text: It affects the mucosal membrane of the nose only.
The recommended course of primary treatment is Dapsone
The causative agent cannot be cultured in vitro
It is not associated with contaminated water exposure

questions.solution:
Answer: C) The causative agent cannot be cultured in vitro.

 

 

Explanation:

Rhinosporidium seeberi is a eukaryotic pathogen that exhibits characteristics of both fungi and protozoa, making it difficult to culture in laboratory settings.

Rhinosporidiosis

  • Chronic granulomatous infection caused by Rhinosporidium seeberi
  • Primarily affects mucosal membranes of: (Option A ruled out)
    • Nose
    • Nasopharynx
    • Conjunctiva
    • Urethra
  • Endemic in tropical and subtropical regions; associated with contaminated water exposure (Option D ruled out)

Microbiology of Rhinosporidiosis

Aspect

Details

Causative Agent
  • Rhinosporidium seeberi - eukaryotic pathogen exhibiting features of fungi and protozoa; cannot be cultured in vitro (Option C)

Pathogenesis
  • Occurs via endospores infecting traumatized mucosal surfaces, leading to hyperplastic growths and rhinosporidial polyps

Histopathology
  • Presence of thick-walled sporangia (50-1000 μm) filled with endospores (5-10 μm)
  • Surrounding tissue shows hyperplasia and infiltration by inflammatory cells (lymphocytes, plasma cells)
  • The lack of eosinophilic infiltration distinguishes it from similar infections.

Staining Techniques
  • H&E: Identifies sporangia and inflammatory response
  • PAS: Stains endospores positively
  • GMS: Visualizes fungal elements

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

Clinical Presentation

  • Nasal Masses:
    • Soft, fleshy lesions, pedunculated or flat
    • Red or granular appearance with yellowish-white dots (mature sporangia)
  • Symptoms:
    • Nasal obstruction
    • Epistaxis (nosebleeds)
    • Discharge

Diagnosis

  • Histopathology:
    • Definitive through examination of excised tissue showing characteristic sporangia and inflammation.
  • Clinical History:
    • Important to note exposure to stagnant water or endemic areas.

Treatment

Treatment Option

Details

Surgical Intervention

Wide surgical excision of lesions.

Cauterization of base is recommended to minimize recurrence.

Adjunctive Therapy

Postoperative Dapsone is used to prevent recurrence, though efficacy is controversial due to resistance. (Option B ruled out)

questions.text: A biopsy from a cutaneous lesion in a patient with suspected sporotrichosis is examined under a microscope. Which of the following findings would strongly support the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Answer: C) Cigar-shaped yeast cells

 

Explanation:

Sporothrix schenckii in the yeast phase is often described as cigar-shaped, which helps differentiate it from other fungi.

Explanation:

Sporothrix schenckii in the yeast phase is often described as cigar-shaped, which helps differentiate it from other fungi.

 

Sporotrichosis

Causative agent

Dimorphic fungus Sporothrix schenckii.

Epidemiology

Common in gardeners, forest workers, and manual labourers.

Route of transmission

Minor trauma or thorn prick.

Clinical features

Chronic infection affects cutaneous, subcutaneous, and lymphatic tissue.

Lesions form at sites of minor trauma or thorn pricks, starting as nodules.

Nodules ulcerate and necrose; infection spreads through lymphatic channels.

Lymphocutaneous sporotrichosis: Secondary ulcers on lymph nodes; lymphatics become hardened and cord-like.

Systemic dissemination: Can affect bones, joints, and meninges.

Specimens

Aspiration from nodules and biopsy material.

Diagnosis

 

Microscopy:

  • KOH mounts or histopathological sections stained by methenamine silver stain show asteroid bodies (Splendore hoeppli phenomenon)

 

  • Yeast phase: Cigar-shaped cells. (Option C)
 

Culture: Thin septate hyphae with flower-like clusters of small conidia; pear-shaped conidia in rosette-like clusters in mycelial phase.

Serological tests: Helpful for extracutaneous or systemic infections.

 

Treatment

 

Medications:

  • Itraconazole
  • Terbinafine
  • Amphotericin B: For disseminated infection

Cryotherapy.

Thick-walled spherules filled with endospores (Option A): It is characteristic of Coccidioides immitis, the causative agent of coccidioidomycosis. This option is incorrect.

Mariner’s wheel-shaped yeast cells (Option B): It is characteristic of Paracoccidioides brasiliensis, which causes paracoccidioidomycosis. This option is incorrect.

 

Broad-based budding yeast cells (Option D): It is characteristic of Blastomyces dermatitidis, the causative organism of blastomycosis. This option is incorrect.

questions.text: Which of the following statements best describes the typical transmission route of Coccidioides immitis?

choices.text: Insect bite from an endemic vector

questions.solution:
Answer: B) Inhalation of dust containing arthrospores

 

Explanation:

Coccidioides immitis is transmitted through the inhalation of dust containing fungal arthrospores, especially in arid, dusty environments.

Coccidioidomycosis

Causative agent

Thermally dimorphic fungus Coccidioides immitis.

Route of transmission

Inhalation of dust containing fungal arthrospores. (Option B)

Clinical features

Self-limited, flu-like fever ("valley fever" or "desert rheumatism").

Primary pulmonary infection.

Severe cases: Less than 1% develop chronic disseminated disease (coccidioidal granuloma), which can be fatal.

 

Diagnosis

 

In tissue: Spherules with a thick, doubly refractile wall, filled with endospores.

Culture: Mycelial phase with hyphae that fragment into arthrospores. Arthrospores are infective.

Skin test: Positive delayed hypersensitivity with "coccidioidin."

Treatment

 

Mild cases: Fluconazole or itraconazole.

Severe cases: Amphotericin B.

questions.text: A 50-year-old immunocompromised patient presents with cough, fever, weight loss, hepatosplenomegaly, and lymphadenopathy. She reports having recently cleaned out an old barn where she encountered large amounts of bird droppings. Upon examination, she has mild tachycardia and her lungs exhibit scattered crackles on auscultation. A chest X-ray shows patchy infiltrates and several calcified nodules. Histopathology and (LPCB) mount of colonies grown in culture are shown below. Which of the following is the most appropriate treatment?
questions.solution:
Answer: B) Amphotericin-B by itraconazole

 

Explanation:

  • Based on the patient’s history, histopathology showing intramacrophagic yeast form and (LPCB) mount showing numerous hyaline hyphae with few tuberculate macroconidia (arrows) and many smooth-walled oval microconidia are pointing towards a diagnosis of disseminated histoplasmosis.
  • The recommended treatment for disseminated histoplasmosis, especially in immunocompromised patients, is Amphotericin-B. After stabilization, itraconazole is prescribed usually for a year to prevent recurrence and manage the infection.

Histoplasmosis

Causative Agent

Histoplasma capsulatum; thermally dimorphic fungus.

  • H. capsulatum var. capsulatum: Causes classical histoplasmosis.
  • H. capsulatum var. duboisii: Causes African histoplasmosis.

Epidemiology

Endemic to central and eastern USA; also found in Africa.

Route of transmission

Thrives in soil, decaying trees, and bird droppings.

Inhalation of fungal spores.

Clinical manifestations

Classical histoplasmosis is often asymptomatic.

Calcified lesions.

Pulmonary disease mimics tuberculosis.

Disseminated histoplasmosis can occur.

Infection of the reticuloendothelial system causes:

  • Lymphadenopathy, hepatosplenomegaly, fever, and anaemia

Skin and mucous membrane: Granulomatous and ulcerative lesions.

African Histoplasmosis:

  • It primarily affects the skin, subcutaneous tissues, and bones
  • Lungs are rarely involved, and disseminated cases are infrequent

Specimens for Diagnosis

Blood, urine, bone marrow, lesions

 

Diagnosis

Microscopy:

  • Stained smears of the specimens show small intra- and extracellular yeast cells
 

Culture:

  • Blood agar and Sabouraud agar show characteristic growth
  • White, cottony, mycelial growth with large thick-walled spherical spores with tuberculate (finger-like projections)
 

Serodiagnosis:

  • Antibody titers increase in progressive disease
  • Antigen tests on urine and serum are helpful for immunocompromised individuals.

Skin Test:

  • Delayed hypersensitivity to histoplasmin confirms exposure

Treatment

Amphotericin-B for two to four weeks followed by a year of itraconazole (Option A ruled out)

 

Fluconazole (Option C): It is usually reserved for less severe infections or maintenance therapy after initial treatment with more potent antifungals like amphotericin-B. This option is incorrect.

Surgical resection (Option D): It may be considered for localized infections or complications like abscesses, but it is not appropriate as a primary treatment strategy for disseminated histoplasmosis.

questions.text:
A 40-year-old male from North America presents with cough, fever, and weight loss. Chest imaging shows focal consolidation in the lungs, and he has developed ulcerative skin lesions on his face as shown below. A skin biopsy is performed, and the sample is sent for GMS staining. An image of the GMS stain is shown below. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?


{{caption_text}}
questions.solution:
Answer: A) Blastomycosis

 

Explanation:

Blastomycosis is caused by Blastomyces dermatitidis, a dimorphic fungus commonly found in North America. It often presents with respiratory symptoms (cough, fever, weight loss) and may disseminate to the skin, forming ulcerative lesions. Microscopically, the spherical yeast cells with a thick double-contoured black-coloured wall and a broad-based bud, visible with GMS staining, are classic for blastomycosis, making this the most likely diagnosis.

Blastomycosis

Causative Agent:

Blastomyces dermatitidis, a thermally dimorphic fungus.

Epidemiology

Primarily found in North America; cases are also reported in Africa and Delhi, India.

Route of transmission

Inhalation of fungal spores from contaminated soil.

Clinical manifestations

Acute or chronic infection, characterised by the formation of suppurative and granulomatous lesions with a marked preference for lungs and skin.

Primary Lung Infection: Mimics tuberculosis or histoplasmosis; symptoms vary from asymptomatic to severe with focal consolidation, miliary lesions, or abscesses.

Disseminated Disease: Spreads through the bloodstream, forming multiple abscesses; high fatality rate.

Cutaneous Disease: Begins as a papule, forming large, ulcerative lesions, often on the face or other exposed skin.

 

Diagnosis

Microscopy:

  • Large, thick double-contoured wall, spherical yeast with a single broad-based bud.
  • Grocott's methenamine silver (GMS) stain: Black staining of fungal cell walls.
GMS answer" data-author="" data-hash="10191" data-license="" data-source="" data-tags="April2025" src="https://image.prepladder.com/notes/VJTV83IbwnalK0pMJ51y1744477904.png" />

Culture:

  • Filamentous growth with septate hyphae and round/oval conidia.

Treatment

Itraconazole: For mild to moderate cases.

Amphotericin B: For severe and life-threatening cases.

 

Chromoblastomycosis (Option B): It is a chronic fungal infection, that typically presents as warty, nodular skin lesions, not as ulcerative lesions. It is commonly found in tropical regions and is not associated with lung involvement or systemic symptoms like weight loss. Microscopic examination shows sclerotic bodies. This option is incorrect.

 

Mycotic Mycetoma (Option C): It is caused by the fungi Madurella mycetomatis. It presents as a chronic infection of the skin, subcutaneous tissue, and sometimes bone, usually in the feet. It manifests as nodules that can develop into draining sinuses and does not typically form warty lesions or display sclerotic bodies in microscopy. This option is incorrect.

 

Sporotrichosis (Option D): It is caused by Sporothrix schenckii, often occurs after a traumatic implantation and typically presents with nodular lesions that can ulcerate, forming a lymphatic spread pattern. Microscopy of sporotrichosis shows cigar-shaped yeast cells instead. This option is incorrect.

questions.text: Dimorphic fungi can evade the host immune system primarily through which of the following mechanisms?

choices.text: Conversion to a yeast form in the host

questions.solution:
Answer: B) Conversion to a yeast form in the host

 

Explanation:

In the environment, dimorphic fungi exist in mold form but convert to yeast form in the host (at 37°C). The yeast form is typically more resistant to phagocytosis and immune responses, allowing the fungi to survive and multiply in the host.

 

Dimorphic Fungus

Have the ability to convert between two specific morphologic forms, yeast and hyphae.

Types:

  • Thermally dimorphic fungi:
    • Converts between hyphae (22–25°C) and yeast (37°C), based on the temperature
    • Thermally dimorphic fungi infect humans and other mammals
    • Conversion to yeast within healthy and immunocompromised mammalian hosts is essential for virulence (Option B)
    • Eg. Blastomyces dermatitidis, Histoplasma capsulatum, Coccidioides immitis and posadasii, Paracoccidioides brasiliensis and lutzii, Sporothrix schenckii, Talaromyces marneffei, Emmonsia spp., Lacazia loboi.
  • Nonthermal dimorphic fungi:
    • Typically infects plants

dimorphic fungus.png" data-author="" data-hash="10188" data-license="" data-source="" data-tags="April2025" src="https://image.prepladder.com/notes/UvujaelLftKr86JvtFT61744477430.png" />

Formation of biofilms (Option A): It is a common immune evasion mechanism for Candida, but is not a primary characteristic of dimorphic fungi. This option is incorrect.

Production of endotoxins (Option C): Endotoxins are lipopolysaccharides found in the outer membrane of Gram-negative bacteria, not in fungi. Dimorphic fungi do not produce endotoxins. This option is incorrect.

Direct cell-to-cell transmission (Option D): Dimorphic fungi are primarily transmitted through inhalation of spores from the environment and then converted to the yeast form within the host, rather than spreading directly from cell to cell. This option is incorrect.

questions.text: A 45-year-old male agricultural worker from a rural area presents with an extensive slowly growing, warty, nodular lesion on his lower leg as shown in the image below. The lesion is dark, and rough, and resembles the surface of cauliflower. He recalls injuring his leg on a thorn while working barefoot in the fields several months ago. A KOH mount of the skin specimen is shown below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Answer: B) Chromoblastomycosis

 

Explanation:

Chromoblastomycosis is a fungal infection often seen in individuals from tropical regions who have sustained trauma, such as an injury from a thorn. It commonly presents as slowly growing, warty, nodular lesions resembling cauliflower. The presence of sclerotic bodies (round, dark brown, yeast-like bodies with septate) in KOH mounts is characteristic, making it the most likely diagnosis in this case.

Chromoblastomycosis (Also known as verrucous dermatitis)

Epidemiology

It is the most common form of chromomycosis.

Common among barefoot agricultural workers and woodcutters.

Tropical region.

Causative agents

Fonsecaea pedrosoi, Fonsecaea compacta, Exophiala dermatitidis, Phialophora, Cladophialophora.

Route of transmission

Infecting fungi enter the skin by traumatic implantation.

Clinical manifestation

Warty, cutaneous nodular lesions (resemble the florets of cauliflower).

Usually confined to subcutaneous tissue of the feet and lower legs

Slow-developing lesions around the site of implantation.

Chromoblastomycosis foot" data-author="" data-hash="10182" data-license="" data-source="" data-tags="April2025" src="https://image.prepladder.com/notes/XDM2CdVMChdG0KscAB1w1744476678.png" />

Diagnosis

 

Microscopy: The lesions show the presence of the fungus as round or irregular, dark brown, yeast-like bodies with septate, called sclerotic bodies (other names: muriform bodies, copper pennies, medlar bodies).

Sclerotic cells" data-author="" data-hash="10185" data-license="" data-source="" data-tags="April2025" src="https://image.prepladder.com/notes/vw70kUv1HY15bZZnjgC31744476801.png" />

Demonstration of these sclerotic bodies in KOH mounts or tissue sections, and by culture on Sabouraud agar.

Treatment

Medical: Amphotericin B, thiabendazole, 5-fluorocytosine, itraconazole and (new drug) voriconazole.

Surgical excision.

 

Rhinosporidiosis (Option A): It is a chronic infection caused by Rhinosporidium seeberi. It typically presents as polypoid masses in the nasal cavity, conjunctiva, or other mucosal surfaces, not as warty, nodular skin lesions. KOH mounts do not show sclerotic bodies. This option is incorrect.

Mycotic Mycetoma (Option C): It is caused by the fungi Madurella mycetomatis. It presents as a chronic infection of the skin, subcutaneous tissue, and sometimes bone, usually in the feet. It manifests as nodules that can develop into draining sinuses and does not typically form warty lesions or display sclerotic bodies in microscopy. This option is incorrect.

Sporotrichosis (Option D): It is caused by Sporothrix schenckii, often occurs after a traumatic implantation and typically presents with nodular lesions that can ulcerate, forming a lymphatic spread pattern. Microscopy of sporotrichosis shows cigar-shaped yeast cells instead. This option is incorrect.

questions.text: A 25-year-old male presents with multiple light-coloured patches on his chest and back, which are more noticeable after sun exposure. The lesions are asymptomatic but have not resolved with moisturizers. An image of the Microscopic examination of skin scrapings is shown below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Answer: C) Tinea versicolor

 

Explanation:

Tinea versicolor is caused by Malassezia furfur and presents as hypopigmented or hyperpigmented macular lesions, typically on the chest, back, or upper limbs. It is asymptomatic and diagnosed by finding yeast cells grouped in a “grape bunch” format with short, branched filaments on microscopy.

 

Tinea Versicolor (Pityriasis Versicolor)

  • A superficial fungal infection of the stratum corneum (outer skin layer)
  • Mostly asymptomatic but may lead to visible skin discolouration
  • Prevalent in tropical climates, commonly affecting young adults
  • Causative agent: Malassezia furfur (previously called Pityrosporum orbiculare)
  • Appearance:
    • Presents as discrete or confluent macular lesions
    • Affected areas show pigmentation changes (hypopigmentation or hyperpigmentation)
  • Commonly affected sites:
    • Chest, abdomen, upper limbs, and back

Test/Tool

Findings

Candidiasis (Option D): Presents as erythematous plaques or white patches in moist areas (like skin folds) or mucosal surfaces (oral thrush, vaginal candidiasis). This option is incorrect.

questions.text: Which of the following statements is TRUE regarding the Splendore–Hoeppli phenomenon?

choices.text: It is exclusively seen in functional infections
It is never associated with parasitic infestations
It can occur in both infectious and noninfectious conditions
It does not involve any immune cells

questions.solution:
Answer: C) It can occur in both infectious and noninfectious conditions.

 

Explanation:

The Splendore–Hoeppli phenomenon is seen in a variety of conditions, both infectious (fungal, bacterial, or parasitic infections) and noninfectious (Hypereosinophilic syndrome and allergic conjunctival granulomas).

 

Splendore-Hoeppli phenomenon

  • Splendore–Hoeppli phenomenon (asteroid bodies) involves microorganisms or inert substances surrounded by radiating eosinophilic material
  • Microscopically, it appears as strongly eosinophilic, amorphous material with star-like or club-shaped formations.

  • This phenomenon surrounds or is adjacent to the causative agent
  • It is often accompanied by an inflammatory reaction rich in eosinophils, histiocytes, epithelioid cells, and giant cells (Option D ruled out)

 

Conditions where the phenomenon is seen

Fungal infections
  • Sporotrichosis,
  • pityrosporum folliculitis,
  • Zygomycosis,
  • candidiasis,
  • aspergillosis
  • blastomycosis.

Bacterial infections
  • Botryomycosis,
  • nocardiosis
  • actinomycosis.

Parasitic infestations
  • Orbital pythiosis,
  • strongyloidiasis,
  • schistosomiasis
  • cutaneous larva migrans.

Noninfective pathologies
  • Hypereosinophilic syndrome
  • allergic conjunctival granulomas.

questions.text: A 45-year-old man presents with a chronic, painless nodule on his foot, which has progressively enlarged over the past year. Upon examination, he has draining sinuses with black grains in the exudate. Microscopic examination of the tissue reveals thick-walled grains and hyphae. Which of the following is the most likely causative agent of this condition?
questions.solution:
Answer: C) Madurella mycetomatis

 

Explanation:

Madurella mycetomatis is a common fungal agent associated with eumycetoma and is characterized by the presence of thick-walled grains and hyphae in microscopic examination.

Mycetoma (Madura Foot)

  • Definition: Chronic granulomatous infection with subcutaneous masses, draining sinuses, and grains in exudates
  • Types:
    • Eumycetoma (fungal)
    • Actinomycetoma (bacterial)

 

Clinical Presentation

  • Initial Lesion:
    • Painless nodule; may be asymptomatic for years
  • Progression:
    • Leads to swelling, ulceration, and pus discharge from sinuses containing grains
  • Complications:
    • Severe deformities, osteomyelitis, potential amputation due to extensive tissue damage

 

Microscopic Examination

Type

Causative Agents

Microscopic Features

Eumycetoma

Madurella mycetomatis, (Option C) Curvularia lunata, Scedosporium spp., Acremonium spp.

Hyphae or thick-walled grains (black/white).

Histology shows suppurative granulomas with neutrophils.

Actinomycetoma

Actinomadura madurae, Nocardia spp. (Options A & B ruled out)

Thin, branching filaments visible with Gram staining. Similar granulomas to eumycetoma but distinct morphology.

 

 

Diagnostic Techniques

  • Biopsy and Culture:
    • Tissue biopsy for visualization of pathogens.
    • Culturing exudates for specific organism identification.
    • Special stains to differentiate fungal and bacterial infections.
  • Imaging Studies:
    • X-rays and MRI to assess bone involvement in advanced cases.

Treatment

Type

Treatment Approach

Eumycetoma

Surgical excision with antifungals (itraconazole, ketoconazole). High recurrence rates.

Actinomycetoma

Prolonged antibiotic therapy (e.g., trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole, dapsone) along with surgical intervention.

 

Trichophyton rubrum (Option D): It is a foot fungus responsible for tinea pedis (athlete's foot). It does not produce the thick-walled grains characteristic of eumycetoma. This option is incorrect.

questions.text: Which statement is correct regarding the use of Wood’s lamp in dermatology?

choices.text: It is not useful for diagnosing scalp infections as hair blocks fluorescence
It is done in a bright room using ultraviolet light
Normal skin will fluoresce bright pink under Wood’s lamp
Microsporum infections commonly fluoresce bright greenish-yellow under Wood's lamp

questions.solution:
Answer: D) Microsporum infections commonly fluoresce bright greenish-yellow under Wood's lamp.

 

Explanation:

Microsporum infections are known for their bright greenish-yellow fluorescence, under Wood's lamp.

 

Wood's lamp examination for detecting superficial fungal infections

  • Procedure: It is done in a dark room using ultraviolet light on the area of interest (Option B ruled out)

questions.text: A 28-year-old patient presents with hair loss and scalp lesions. A hair perforation test is performed to differentiate between Trichophyton rubrum and Trichophyton mentagrophytes. Which of the following statements about the hair perforation test is true?

choices.text: Microscopically hair is examined with Grocott's methenamine silver (GMS) stain
T. mentagrophytes exhibits surface erosion of the hair shaft.

questions.solution:
Answer: D) T. mentagrophytes exhibits surface erosion of the hair shaft.

 

Explanation:

T. mentagrophytes causes a characteristic wedge-shaped appearance due to surface erosion of the hair shaft.

 

Hair Perforation Test

  • Purpose: Differentiate between Trichophyton rubrum and Trichophyton mentagrophytes.

Procedure

  1. Place strands of human hair in a petri dish with 20 ml of distilled water.
  2. Autoclave the dish.
  3. Add sterile 10% yeast extract and fragments of the test fungus to the hair.
  4. Incubate at 25°C for 2-3 weeks. (Option A ruled out)
  5. Examine the hair microscopically with a lactophenol cotton blue-stained wet preparation. (Option C ruled out)

Test Results

  • If T. mentagrophytes is present:
    • The hair shaft appears wedge-shaped due to surface erosion. (Option B ruled out) (Option D)

Characteristics of Fungal Infections:

  • Both T. rubrum and T. mentagrophytes cause ectothrix hair infections, where arthrospores form a sheath around the hair.
  • T. rubrum is the most common dermatophyte in humans, often leading to chronic, treatment-resistant lesions.

Identification Methods

Method

Description

Macroscopic examination

Assess the growth rate, texture, and colour on media

Urea hydrolysis test

Determines ability to hydrolyze urea

Growth on polished rice or special media

Tests the ability to grow in specific conditions

Temperature tolerance test

Assesses resistance to elevated temperatures

Nutritional requirements test

Checks requirements for specific amino acids and vitamin

questions.text: A 28-year-old male presents with a pruritic rash in the groin area. Upon examination, the lesion is erythematous with raised borders and has a clear centre. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis based on the anatomical classification of dermatophytosis?
questions.solution:
Answer: C) Tinea cruris

 

Explanation:

Tinea cruris is a condition, commonly known as jock itch, specifically affects the groin and perineum, characterized by erythema and raised borders.

 

Classification of Dermatophytosis

Anatomic Classification

Dermatophytosis can be classified based on the affected anatomical site:

Tinea barbae

Infection of the bearded areas of the face and neck (barber's itch). (Option A ruled out)

Tinea capitis

Tinea corporis

Classification by Genus

Microsporum

Predominantly macroconidia; spindle-shaped, multicellular structures; infects hair and skin.

Trichophyton

More abundant microconidia in clusters; macroconidia are thin, and elongated; include species like T. rubrum which is common in humans. Infects hair, nails and skin.

Epidermophyton

Lacks microconidia; club-shaped, multicellular macroconidia; infects skin and nails but not hair.

Types of Conidia

  • Microconidia: Small, unicellular conidia.
  • Macroconidia: Larger, multicellular, septate conidia.

questions.text: A 10-year-old child presents with hair loss and black dot tinea capitis. Microscopic examination of the hair reveals elongated hyphae within the hair shaft. Which of the following statements is true regarding the likely condition the child has?

choices.text: It is commonly associated with Microsporum canis
It typically involves Trichophyton tonsurans and Trichophyton violaceum
The treatment of choice is typically 2 weeks

questions.solution:
Answer: C) It typically involves Trichophyton tonsurans and Trichophyton violaceum.

 

Explanation:

  • Trichophyton tonsurans and Trichophyton violaceum are the primary fungi responsible for endothrix infections, where the fungus penetrates the hair shaft, leading to less contagious forms of tinea capitis, such as black dot tinea capitis.
  • This distinguishes them from Microsporum canis, which causes ectothrix infections characterized by superficial hair involvement and is more contagious.

 

Hair perforation test:

  • The hair perforation test is a diagnostic procedure used in dermatology to evaluate the presence of certain fungal infections, particularly Trichophyton species, which can cause scalp or skin conditions such as ringworm.
  • This test assesses the ability of a hair to be penetrated or perforated by fungal elements, offering insight into whether a fungal infection may be affecting the hair

Dermatophyte Infections: Endothrix vs. Ectothrix

Endothrix

  • Characteristics
    • Invasion: Fungi invade and grow inside the hair shaft, with arthroconidia present within the hair; the cuticle remains intact.
    • Common Species: Trichophyton tonsurans, Trichophyton violaceum (non-inflammatory tinea capitis). (Option C)
    • Clinical Presentation: Presents as black dot tinea capitis; less contagious than ectothrix.
  • Diagnosis
    • Microscopy: Shows elongated hyphae within the hair.
    • Trichoscopy: Features comma-shaped and corkscrew hairs.
  • Treatment

Antifungal Therapy: Griseofulvin; treatment duration: 6-12 weeks.(Option D ruled out)

 

Ectothrix

  • Characteristics
    • Invasion: Fungi grow on the hair shaft surface, degrading the cuticle; hyphae and arthroconidia are on both the surface and inside the hair.
    • Common Species: Microsporum canis (inflammatory tinea capitis). (Option B ruled out)
    • Clinical Presentation: Appears as grey patch tinea capitis; spreads rapidly.
  • Diagnosis
    • Microscopy: Fungal structures on the hair shaft's exterior.
    • Trichoscopy: Features perifollicular scaling. (Option A ruled out)
  • Treatment
    • Antifungal Therapy: Griseofulvin; treatment duration may be longer.

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

The hair perforation test is a diagnostic tool used to differentiate dermatophyte species. It involves incubating hair with a fungal isolate in a sterile solution and examining for wedge-shaped perforations under a microscope.

Interpretation:

  • Positive test: Presence of wedge-shaped perforations in the hair shaft (e.g., Trichophyton mentagrophytes).
  • Negative test: Absence of perforations (e.g., Trichophyton rubrum).

questions.text: A 25-year-old male presents with dark, hard nodules along his scalp hair, which he mistakenly believes to be lice nits. Upon microscopic examination, branched hyphae and arthrospores are observed. Which of the following is the most likely cause of his condition?
questions.solution:
Answer: B) Piedraia hortae

 

Explanation:

Piedraia hortae is the causative agent of black piedra, characterized by dark nodules on scalp hair and the presence of branched hyphae and arthrospores upon microscopic examination.

Piedra Infection

  • Superficial fungal infection affecting hair shaft.
  • Characterized by nodules.
  • Two main types: Black Piedra and White Piedra.

Black Piedra

Aspect

Details

Etiology

Caused by Piedraia hortae (dematiaceous fungus) (Option B).

Characteristics

Affects scalp hair; it is common in individuals with long hair and poor hygiene.

Clinical Features

Hard, black nodules that may resemble lice nits; complex structure of filamentous hyphae and spores; examined using KOH shows branched hyphae and arthrospores.

Diagnosis

Direct microscopic examination:

Branched hyphae and arthrospores

Culture:

Sabouraud dextrose agar shows dark colonies.

Treatment

Antifungal shampoos or systemic antifungals; treatment efficacy may be compromised by nodules' compact nature.

 

White Piedra

Aspect

Details

Etiology

Caused by Trichosporon species, commonly Trichosporon beigelli, Trichosporon inkin (Option A ruled out).

Characteristics

Affects facial, axillary, and pubic hair; typically asymptomatic.

Clinical Features

Whitish, loosely adherent nodules consisting of arthroconidia and blastoconidia.

Diagnosis

KOH examination and culture reveal yeast-like colonies.

Treatment

Topical antifungals such as ketoconazole shampoo.

 

 

Mixed Piedra

  • Rare condition involving both black and white piedra
  • Presents with both dark and light nodules
  • Requires careful mycological examination for accurate diagnosis

Candida albicans (Option C): Candida albicans do not cause superficial fungal infections of the hair shaft like piedra. Microscopy shows Candida yeast with pseudohyphae. This option is incorrect.

 

Malassezia furfur (Option D): Malassezia furfur do not cause piedra. It primarily affects the skin and is involved in conditions related to skin oiliness rather than hard nodules along the hair shaft. Microscopy shows yeast cells grouped in a “grape bunch” format with short, branched filaments or spaghetti and meatball appearance. This option is incorrect.

questions.text: A 25-year-old woman from a tropical region presents with a brown, macular lesion on the palm of her hand. There is no itching or scaling. Microscopic examination of skin scrapings reveals brownish, branched, septate hyphae along with budding cells. What is the most likely causative agent?
questions.solution:
Answer: B) Exophiala werneckii

 

Explanation:

Exophiala werneckii causes Tinea nigra, characterized by black or brown macular lesions on the palms, with microscopy showing brown septate hyphae and budding cells.

 

Tinea Nigra

  • Definition: A superficial fungal infection limited to the stratum corneum
  • Geography: Common in tropical climates
  • Clinical Presentation:
    • Black or brown macular lesions on the skin
    • Frequently affects the palms
  • Causative Agents:
    • Exophiala werneckii (previously Cladosporium wernickii / Hortaea wernickii)
    • Exophiala castellanii

Diagnosis of Tinea Nigra:

  • Microscopy (skin scrapings):
    • Brownish, branched, septate hyphae
    • Budding cells

 

 

  • Culture:
    • Sabouraud agar: Colonies appear grey or black
